comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content: I believe these tram stops were on Colmore Row and that the large building in the background is the old Post Office at the west end of New Street.  The Number 10 route went out to Washwood Heath, the stop in front will be the Number 8 to Alum Rock.

comment.author: 52390279@N04
comment._content: An excellent photograph. It takes me back a few years to the 1930s!

comment.author: 36844288@N00
comment._content: Birmingham (and the adjoining Black Country network) was unusual for a UK conurbation in that the 3ft 6in gauge (not standard 4ft 8.5in) was used - car 804 was one of a batch built in 1928/9 with Brush bodywork. It is one of the few Birmingham cars (routes 8 & 10?) that was fitted with a bow collector rather than the usual trolley pole. Retired at Last - I think this terminus was in Martineau Street?

comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/36844288@N00]  You could well be right, I no longer think the background building is the old post office.  It's a pity that the Martineau Street area has been redeveloped, possibly twice, since this photo, so we can't even try looking on the ground for an answer.

comment.author: 41701047@N08
comment._content:
Mikeyashworth is quite correct this is Martineau St, the terminus of the 10 Route from Washwood Heath. From stand 3 the trams turned straight into Corporation Street.
 In David Harvey's book Birmingham trams 1933-1953 volume 1 there is a picture in Martineau St albeit looking down rather than up that shows a number 8 which terminated at the same place.
This is a superb shot, so crisp and well scanned

comment.author: 16101541@N04
comment._content: Car 804 is standing in Martineau Street at the 10 route's City terminus with the shops in Corporation Stret in the distance.  The tram entered service in January 1929 and is in the street before it became a one-way street in 1933.
